summary_variants.short_answer: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants, algae, and some bacteria convert light energy into chemical energy stored in sugars.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: Photosynthesis lets plants use sunlight, air, and water to make their own food and release oxygen for us to breathe.
summary_variants.standard: Photosynthesis is a biochemical process in which light-harvesting pigments capture photons to drive reactions that split water, fix carbon dioxide via the Calvin cycle, and produce carbohydrates and oxygen. It underpins most food chains and global oxygen supply.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Mention PSI/PSII dynamics, electron transport chains, rubisco limitations, and the difference between C3, C4, and CAM pathways.

slots.definition: A light-dependent metabolic pathway that converts solar energy into chemical energy by fixing carbon dioxide and splitting water, releasing oxygen as a byproduct.
key_characteristics: Occurs in chloroplast thylakoid membranes (light reactions) and stroma (Calvin cycle)
Uses chlorophyll and accessory pigments to capture specific wavelengths
Splits water to provide electrons, releasing oxygen
Fixes CO2 into triose phosphates that become sugars and starch
applications: Supports bioengineering efforts to enhance crop yields
Inspires artificial photosynthesis and solar fuel research
limitations: Rubisco inefficiency and photorespiration at high temperatures
Requires adequate light, water, and nutrient availability
Sensitive to pollution and climate stress
history: Jan Ingenhousz demonstrated light-dependent oxygen release in 1779
Calvin, Bassham, and Benson mapped the carbon fixation cycle (Calvin cycle)
Modern work explores genetic modification of photosystems

meta.review_notes: 2025-11-15: Checked definitions and process description against Campbell Biology (12th ed.) and Britannica.
